source.absolute_timeline_notes: Chase arrives in Broken Bow Free City for emergency cybermancy following Fox River’s destruction.

text_windows.full_scene_clean: Chase wakes on a cold metal table under a harsh spotlight, body unresponsive except for his left eye. Music hums distantly; ad panels around the room hawk chrome limbs and synthetic mods. Wires and tubing lace the ceiling. Realization stings: Fox River is gone. Quincy leans into the light—worried, uncharacteristically tender—and tells him a cybermancer needs his consent before treatment. Lesha, calm and steady, backs her up. Chase is immobilized by a nerve block, mind skittering between panic and trust. After Quincy begs, he croaks, “I… I consent,” and relief floods her face before she snaps back into problem-solving mode. The cybermancer shuffles into view: goggles like insect eyes, too-many metal fingers ending in tools, a hookah’s spiced smoke curling as he works. Quincy bristles at the smoke; Lesha’s hand on her shoulder cools the fuse. The cybermancer explains he records consent so patients don’t wake missing pieces they never agreed to lose. He strips the blanket, lays a bleach-wet sheet on Chase’s skin, fits a mask that smells faintly of machine oil and then eucalyptus, and shoos the others to a waiting room. As sedation thickens, the doctor’s segmented hands slot new tips with tiny clicks. “Don’t fight it,” he murmurs. “You have good friends.” The fog closes over Chase; darkness takes him as the procedure begins.
text_windows.dense_recap_250w: In a gritty clinic in Broken Bow Free City, Chase regains partial consciousness on a metal table, immobile from a nerve block and panicking. Quincy and Lesha hover nearby, having brought him to a cybermancer for emergency repair. Quincy, rattled but resolute, urges him to grant consent; the cybermancer refuses to operate without recorded agreement. Chase, recognizing Quincy’s worry and trusting his friends, finally says he consents. The cybermancer—a spidery figure with goggled eyes, multi-jointed cybernetic hands tipped with surgical tools, and a hookah sending spiced smoke into the air—prepares the operation. Tension spikes when he blows smoke in Quincy’s direction, but Lesha de-escalates and keeps Quincy focused on Chase. The cybermancer lays a bleach-soaked sheet on Chase, fits a breathing mask that shifts to a calming eucalyptus scent, and begins swapping tool heads while explaining that consent prevents disputes when patients wake to unexpected losses. He dismisses Quincy and Lesha to a waiting room and sedates Chase, who slips into darkness as the procedure starts. The scene centers on consent, vulnerability, and loyalty amid body-horror tech: Quincy’s awkward tenderness, Lesha’s steadiness, and a clinician whose ethics coexist with clinical detachment and grime. Outcome: surgery commences; Chase’s fate and extent of augmentation remain unknown.

embedding_payloads.text: In a grim cybermancer clinic in Broken Bow, an immobilized Chase wakes on a metal table as Quincy and Lesha push him to grant consent for emergency repairs. The cybermancer—goggled, multi-tooled, and smoking a hookah—refuses to operate without it. After Chase agrees, tension flares between Quincy and the doctor but is defused by Lesha. The doc lays a bleach-wet sheet, fits a scented mask, swaps tool heads, and sedates Chase, promising it will be fine. The operation begins; outcomes are unknown.

Entities: Chase (injured patient); Quincy (protective ally); Lesha (steady de-escalator); Cybermancer (unnamed, clinician). Tech/props: nerve block, modular cyber-hands, anesthesia mask with eucalyptus scent valve, hookah rig, bleach sheet, holo-ad panels, metal table. Locations: Broken Bow Free City; unlicensed cybermancer clinic. Roles: Quincy secures consent; Lesha stabilizes team dynamics; Cybermancer prepares and sedates; Chase submits.

Third-limited, past tense, with gritty clinical body-horror textures: smoke, bleach, cold steel, insectile tools. Themes center on consent and bodily autonomy, loyalty under pressure, and survival through invasive tech. Motifs recur—harsh light vs. darkness, commodified flesh via mod ads, and soothing scents masking fear—posing the question of what informed consent means under duress and how much of oneself can be traded to live.
